awd_titl_txt: CyberTraining: CDL: Cyber Infrastructure Training and Mentoring (CI-TraM)
awd_abstract_narration:
The Cyber Infrastructure Training and Mentoring (CI-TraM) project serves the national interest by developing and increasing the cyberinfrastructure (CI) literacy of undergraduates who are interested in STEM careers.  It does this through technical training and career mentoring focused around building knowledge in CI.  CI-TraM provides direct mentoring of new undergraduates by active STEM researchers and IT professionals.  The training will be provided by a diverse group of researchers in CI-intensive domains and CI professionals.  Topics will include network and data security, high performance computing, computer architecture, and data analytics tools to provide the background to explore computing in a) cybersecurity, b) patterns discovery in biological data, c) computational physics, d) neuroscience, e) game design and human-computer interaction, etc.  This will help address the challenge of creating a future STEM workforce that has the technical and professional skills needed to promote the progress of science; to advance the national health, prosperity and welfare; or to secure the national defense.  The CI-TraM program, developed in a Hispanic Serving Institution (NMSU), cultivates untapped talent within a growing, yet underrepresented, population in STEM careers. The model used for community engagement and student recruitment addresses the transitions between secondary education, post-secondary education, and individual career planning and management.  The CI-TraM model will be designed to become institutionalized with the ability to be replicated in other communities.

The main goals of the CI-TraM program are: 1) To develop a program that exposed and retains students in CI-STEM fields while teaching them valuable technical and life skills needed for successfully pursing, attaining, and maintaining careers, and 2) To develop a program that is sustainable and scalable to other institutions so that other student populations may benefit from the program.  The program utilizes common job site internship procedures in area high schools that provide dual/concurrent college credit.  The CI-TraM program will create a cohort of students interns each academic semester and summer (50/yr) that have demonstrated interest/ability in STEM career pathways.  To achieve Goal 1, technical training and career planning modules developed and taught by working STEM researchers and IT professionals will be completed by each student intern.  At the start and finish of the program a general assessment of a student's knowledge will be performed, and each module would have a tangible deliverable to evaluate student understanding and progress throughout the program.  The program itself will be assessed by a longitudinal follow up that will track students into their futures.  Assessment results will be used by the program coordinators in a continual improvement process.  To achieve Goal 2, the modules will be generated using a standard Learning Management System allowing them to be transferable to other universities.  External consultant-created rubrics will be used to evaluate the modules and their efficacy as well as the efficacy of the modules together as the body of the CI-TraM program and available for others to use.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The CyberInfrastructure: Training and Mentorship (CI:TraM) program was designed for high school and other dual credit students to explore career options and gain technical skills.  The program worked with local high schools and brought juniors and seniors onto the New Mexico State University (NMSU) campus for engagement.  The program supported over 80 students in learning public speaking; career networking; career exploration; learning more about the resources on a university campus; elevator pitches; and technical skills, such as collaboration software, Excel, basic coding, and digital portfolio creation.

            Intellectual merit came in the form of creating sharable digital content and creating a new and effective way to engage with the local community and potential students.  The concepts that were taught are not new, but a holistic, agnostic approach to exploring career paths seems to be.  Our program was life-altering for its participants.

            The main broader impact of CI:TraM was providing a safe space for students to explore career paths.  NMSU is a minority-serving institution (MSI) located in southern New Mexico, surrounded by rural communities, with a large first-generation student and undocumented population.  Many students have little-to-no socio-economic safety net.  They can't afford to explore majors or not finish a degree.  The CI:TraM program is personalized to each student, who takes the lead on exploring career options, both immediate and after graduation.  One activity is to explore the cost of universities, financial aid options, pathways from community colleges to 4-year institutions, and certifications.  The students were startled to find that based on their desired discipline the "best" option changed, and many discovered additional financial aid options.  Some students were shocked to discover that they needed an associate degree or certifications to pursue their desired careers.  The CI:TraM program is designed to support the students in achieving their goals, not steering them towards an end.

"(CI:TraM) really does bring to light a lot of the different software, technical skills, a lot of the different certifications that you need in order to achieve your career goal. So it really does make you look at where you're going to go into your education. What exactly you need to learn for what branch of your career field." - CI:TraM intern, 2021

The program, through its student-led approach, allowed and supported its participants to gain confidence when speaking to others and in their own abilities.  When speaking to the external evaluator, some students realized this internal transformation as well.  

"This program has given me the ability to be comfortable when speaking to professionals and other people involved in my field of interest." - CI:TraM intern, 2019

"The most important skill the CI:TraM internship taught me how to improve my communication skills via public speaking, reaching out to and interviewing professionals. Another thing that I found important was learning how to market myself better." - CI:TraM intern, 2020

The CI:TraM program is also designed to increase technical knowledge and skills.  Seen through the lens of career-readiness, the technical skills were designed by NMSU faculty, researchers, and staff via Canvas (a learning management system) so students could self-serve technical skills based on whether they knew their career goals or if they were still exploring various options.

"The most useful software I practiced in CI-TraM was AutoCAD because I am pursuing an engineering career and my job involves 3d modeling." - CI:TraM intern, 2020

"One of the best technical topics I learned was virtual machines, and how to how to use those?I had never really looked into them at all?and now I know how to create and use one, things like that. Also MySQL. I'm a lot more well versed in that now because of this program." - CI:TraM intern, 2021

Depending on the high school, the students were with the program one or two semesters.  The first semester in the program, students conduct their career advice interviews and explore the technical modules.  When ready, students use the connections they created for themselves the year prior to find placements for more in-depth career exploration.

"(In my internship placement) I learned the everyday operation of NMSU's networking infrastructure and day to day jobs and tasks of IT professionals." - CI:TraM intern, 2020

The CI:TraM program lives on in the form of a dual-credit course at the sister community college and various aspects have been integrated into other programs at NMSU.  CI:TraM is especially important for those students who don?t have a mentor as they transition from high school into the next phase of their lives.

"Even when I applied to NMSU and for the scholarships, I realized I was relying on CI-TraM experiences a lot more than if I didn't have it, I probably wouldn't know what to say. And so, it really helped me gain a lot of skill and knowledge in the field." - CI:TraM intern, 2021


Last Modified: 09/30/2021
Modified by: Diana V Dugas

The CyberInfrastructure: Training and Mentorship (CI:TraM) program was designed for high school and other dual credit students to explore career options and gain technical skills.  The program worked with local high schools and brought juniors and seniors onto the New Mexico State University (NMSU) campus for engagement.  The program supported over 80 students in learning public speaking; career networking; career exploration; learning more about the resources on a university campus; elevator pitches; and technical skills, such as collaboration software, Excel, basic coding, and digital portfolio creation.

            Intellectual merit came in the form of creating sharable digital content and creating a new and effective way to engage with the local community and potential students.  The concepts that were taught are not new, but a holistic, agnostic approach to exploring career paths seems to be.  Our program was life-altering for its participants.

            The main broader impact of CI:TraM was providing a safe space for students to explore career paths.  NMSU is a minority-serving institution (MSI) located in southern New Mexico, surrounded by rural communities, with a large first-generation student and undocumented population.  Many students have little-to-no socio-economic safety net.  They can't afford to explore majors or not finish a degree.  The CI:TraM program is personalized to each student, who takes the lead on exploring career options, both immediate and after graduation.  One activity is to explore the cost of universities, financial aid options, pathways from community colleges to 4-year institutions, and certifications.  The students were startled to find that based on their desired discipline the "best" option changed, and many discovered additional financial aid options.  Some students were shocked to discover that they needed an associate degree or certifications to pursue their desired careers.  The CI:TraM program is designed to support the students in achieving their goals, not steering them towards an end.

The program, through its student-led approach, allowed and supported its participants to gain confidence when speaking to others and in their own abilities.  When speaking to the external evaluator, some students realized this internal transformation as well.  
"This program has given me the ability to be comfortable when speaking to professionals and other people involved in my field of interest." - CI:TraM intern, 2019

The CI:TraM program is also designed to increase technical knowledge and skills. Depending on the high school, the students were with the program one or two semesters.  The first semester in the program, students conduct their career advice interviews and explore the technical modules.  When ready, students use the connections they created for themselves the year prior to find placements for more in-depth career exploration.
"(In my internship placement) I learned the everyday operation of NMSU's networking infrastructure and day to day jobs and tasks of IT professionals." - CI:TraM intern, 2020

The CI:TraM program lives on in the form of a dual-credit course at the sister community college and various aspects have been integrated into other programs at NMSU.  CI:TraM is especially important for those students who don?t have a mentor as they transition from high school into the next phase of their lives.
